title: About
text: This website is associated with course ME/AER 676 Robot Modeling and Control offered at the University of Kentucky. Course created by Hasan A. Poonawala.

title: Overview
text:
Syllabus

Lecture: Tue & Thur 2:00pm - 3:15pm, FPAT 253.
Office Hours: TBD
Text: Notes +Modern Robotics+ Robot Modeling and Control
Workload: 2.5 hours of lecture, 8 hours of reading notes, papers, and writing simulation code per week.
Course announcements: I use canvas to send information, but don’t read inbox messages. Contacting me by email with [ME 676 RMC]: or [AER 676 RMC]: makes it easy for me to track and respond to your emails.
Course website: All course material will be available on the website, which will be updated as the course proceeds.

text:

Accommodations due to disability
Attendance Policy
Classroom Conduct
Excused Absences & Verification of Absences
Exams: None.
Homework: Weekly assignments, must adhere to rules in syllabus
Grading: See Syllabus. Subject to change.

title: Overview
text:
About me

Grew up in England and India
Undergraduate degree in Mech. Engg. in India
Masters in Mech. Engg from U. Michigan
Ph.D in Electrical Engg. from UT Dallas
PostDoc at UT Austin in Computational Control





Research


Goal: Get mechanical robots to control themselves.
Day-to-day: Theory from dynamics and control systems, simulations/experiments involving machine learning and robots.

Touch feedback

Previous: Will the prototype work?
Now: Will this be a viable commercial product?

title: Overview
text:
Tasks For Robots

What kinds of tasks requires a physical robot? (Or, what can’t your phone do?)
How would you describe the motion you want to a robot?
How would you, as a robot, convert that description into action?

title: Overview
text:
Course Overview






Learning Goal


For you to be able to read and assimilate both recent papers and early foundational papers on robotics. Furthermore, develop programming skills that enable you to implement and try (possibly new) methods in simulation.

title: Overview
text:
Course Overview
Learning Goals:

Understand coordinates and robot configurations.
Understand how to transform the robot configuration into task coordinates and vice versa, along with the challenges in these processes.
Learn approaches to planning motions in both task coordinates and robot configurations.
Learn approaches to achieving planned motions using feedback control.
Understand the challenges of state estimation.
Learn optimization-based approaches to planning and control.
Understand contact modeling and control challenges.
Simulate robotic systems and test control algorithms.

title: Overview
text:
Course Overview
Approaches for achieving goals:


Lecture/Discussion on

Coordinates
Dynamical Systems: single and articulated rigid bodies
Planning Trajectories
Sensing and State Estimation
Feedback Control

Research article discussions
Practice through assignments (code and question) and Course Project

title: Overview
text:
Expectations

You are reviewing notes and slides.
Comfort with mathematics:

Abstract definitions.
Imagining concrete examples to which they apply.
Applying definitions to complete derivations and proofs.

Comfort with code:

How to use documentation describing installation and use of packages.
Awareness of the need to test code frequently tests will need testing.

Study groups. Don’t go this one alone.

title: Overview
text:
About You

Name
First robot you were aware of and/or Favorite robot
Motivation for taking this course
Concerns about the course
Topics you wish were on the syllabus
Topics you have already studied
Learning/teaching styles that you feel work well for you

title: Robot Modeling Control
text:
This course covers methods for planning and executing the movement of mobile robots (navigation), robot arms (manipulation) and legs (manipulation).
Course github: poonawalalab/robotics-course

title: Getting Started
text:
We use the following major packages in python:

numpy: working with \(n\)-D arrays
mujoco : Modeling and simulation of robotic systems
matplotlib: plotting

The following command uses pip to install these python packages
pip install numpy mujoco matplotlib
If you want to use machine learning, consider the following packages:

torch: training of differentiable models
torchvision: tools for vision models
pandas: working with data
tqdm: progress bars in the command line
scikit-learn: source some classic datasets



Virtual environments allow you to install a custom set of packages with custom package versions for a project.
Inside the dlcourse directory, run
python -m venv code-venv
to create a blank virtual environment.
Activate it, and then install packages. Upon activation, the command line prompt changes to start with the name of the virtual environment. Here, it would be (code-venv):
source code-venv/bin/activate
pip install <packages above>
When you are done, you can run deactivate to return to the default global environment.

title: Getting Started
text:
NumPy
A nice overview of using numpy is located online here.
Two KEY issues to watch out for:

Standard matrix multiplication in numpy uses the @ symbol, not the * symbol. Users coming from Matlab or Julia often trip over this issue a few times until they internalize the new symbol.
2D Arrays are stored in row-major form.
